PostCSS and Source MapsÂ¶

PostCSS has great source maps support. It can read and interpret maps from previous transformation steps, autodetect the format that you expect, and output both external and inline maps.

To ensure that you generate an accurate source map, you must indicate the input and output CSSÂ fileÂ paths â using the options from and to, respectively.

To generate a new source map with the default options, simply set map: true. This will generate anÂ inline source map that contains the source content. If you donât want the map inlined, youÂ canÂ set map.inline: false.

processor
  .process(css, {
    from: 'app.sass.css',
    to:   'app.css',
    map: { inline: false }
  })
  .then(result => {
      result.map //=> '{ "version":3,
                 //      "file":"app.css",
                 //      "sources":["app.sass"],
                 //       "mappings":"AAAA,KAAI" }'
  })

If PostCSS finds source maps from a previous transformation, it will automatically update thatÂ sourceÂ map with the same options.

OptionsÂ¶

If you want more control over source map generation, you can define the map option as an object withÂ the following parameters:

  • inline boolean: indicates that the source map should be embedded in the output CSS asÂ aÂ Base64-encoded comment. By default, it is true. But if all previous maps are external, notÂ inline, PostCSS will not embed the map even if you do not set this option.

    If you have an inline source map, the result.map property will be empty, as the source map willÂ be contained within the text of result.css.

  • prev string, object, boolean or function: source map content from a previous processing step (forÂ example,Â Sass compilation). PostCSS will try to read the previous source map automatically (based on comments within the source CSS), but you can use this option to identify it manually. IfÂ desired, you can omit the previous map with prev: false.

  • sourcesContent boolean: indicates that PostCSS should set the origin content (forÂ example,Â SassÂ source) of the source map. By default, it is true. But if all previous maps do not contain sources content, PostCSS will also leave it out even if you do not set this option.

  • annotation boolean or string: indicates that PostCSS should add annotation comments toÂ theÂ CSS. By default, PostCSS will always add a comment with a path to the source map. PostCSS will not add annotations to CSS files that do not contain any comments.

    By default, PostCSS presumes that you want to save the source map as opts.to + '.map' andÂ will use this path in the annotation comment. A different path can be set by providing aÂ string value for annotation.

    If you have set inline: true, annotation cannot be disabled.

  • from string: by default, PostCSS will set the sources property of the map to the value of the from option. If you want to override this behaviour, you can use map.from to explicitly set the source mapâs sources property. Path should be absolute or relative from generated file (to option in process() method).
